newsitem.title: GERMANY: No confirmation of Salamander takeover reports.
newsitem.headline: No confirmation of Salamander takeover reports.

text.p: Speculation intensfied on Wednesday that German shoemaker Salamander AG could soon see a major ownership reshuffle.
At the same time shareholders would not confirm newspaper reports forecasting that a change in the group's ownership structure was imminent.
German newspapers reported earlier that Lothar Spaeth, head of the optics company Jenoptik AG was interested in obtaining 20 percent of the company.

A Jenoptik spokesman claimed to know nothing of this, while a Salamander spokeswoman said: "Our shareholders do not tell us what they are doing," adding that Salamander was always delighted when investors expressed an interest in the group.

There was market speculation that a meeting of major shareholders for Wednesday would not result in any decisions on the group's future, amid disappointment among large shareholders after disappointing earnings at Salamander.
There was also speculation that a planned abolition of tax exemptions on wealth tax, capital tax and capital trading tax, on shareholdings of between 10 and 25 percent.
Companies have been queuing up to deny they intend selling their stakes in Salamander, including Deutsche Bank with 10.7 percent, and reinsurer Munich Re which owns a 13.6 percent stake.
Commerzbank, which also owns 10.7 percent, declined to comment.
Other shareholders include J.M. Voith of Austria, with 15 percent and Victoria Lebensversicherung AG with 12.3 percent.
Salamander recently reported lower, albeit stable, sales of 1.33 billion marks for 1996, down from 1.34 billion the previous year.
A report in the Stuttgarter Zeitung said that Salamander would not report a loss of 20 million marks. Salamander would not comment on the report.
Shares in Salamander ended bourse trade in Frankfurt strongly ahead at 209.50 marks, up 2.50 marks, but well off a yearly high of 244.50 marks.
